title: Cancellation
data:
- *For the cancellation effects caused by armor, see [Magic cancellation](/wiki/Magic_cancellation "Magic cancellation").*

**Cancellation** is the term for removing magical charges and [blessed/cursed](/wiki/BUC "BUC") status from an object or disabling the special attack of a monster. The most common source of cancellation is the [wand of cancellation](/wiki/Wand_of_cancellation "Wand of cancellation"). A few are able to use the [spellbook of cancellation](/wiki/Spellbook_of_cancellation "Spellbook of cancellation"). [Magicbane](/wiki/Magicbane "Magicbane") can sometimes cancel things it hits. [Foocubi](/wiki/Foocubi "Foocubi") can spontaneously become cancelled. Some [potions](/wiki/Potion "Potion") can be transformed by dipping [thin](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn")[gs](/wiki/Amethyst_stone "Amethyst stone") in them, but this is not quite cancellation. [Gremlins](/wiki/Gremlin "Gremlin") can also use their intrinsic-stealing attack to cancel other monsters.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Cancellation of objects](#Cancellation_of_objects)

- [2 Cancelling yourself](#Cancelling_yourself)

- [3 Cancellation of monsters](#Cancellation_of_monsters)

  - [3.1 Abilities stopped by cancellation](#Abilities_stopped_by_cancellation)
  - [3.2 Abilities not stopped by cancellation](#Abilities_not_stopped_by_cancellation)
  - [3.3 Notes](#Notes)
  - [3.4 Un-cancelling](#Un-cancelling)

- [4 Cancelling the floor](#Cancelling_the_floor)

- [5 Considering when to cancel](#Considering_when_to_cancel)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)
  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)

- [7 References](#References)

## Cancellation of objects

Cancellation has the following effects on objects:

- the object becomes [uncursed](/wiki/Uncursed "Uncursed")

- the object's enchantment is set to +0 (applies to [weapons](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon"), [weapon-tools](/wiki/Weapon-tool "Weapon-tool"), and [armor](/wiki/Armor "Armor"))

- all charges are removed from the object if it is magical ([wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand") to (x:-1), magical [tools](/wiki/Tool "Tool") to (x:0), [rings](/wiki/Ring "Ring") to +0); non-magical tools, the [wand of nothing](/wiki/Wand_of_nothing "Wand of nothing"), and the [wand of cancellation](/wiki/Wand_of_cancellation "Wand of cancellation") do not lose charges

- [scrolls](/wiki/Scroll "Scroll") and [spellbooks](/wiki/Spellbook "Spellbook") (except the [scroll of mail](/wiki/Scroll_of_mail "Scroll of mail") and [spellbook of cancellation](/wiki/Spellbook_of_cancellation "Spellbook of cancellation")) are blanked

- most [potions](/wiki/Potion "Potion") are converted to uncursed water

  - potions of [see invisible](/wiki/Potion_of_see_invisible "Potion of see invisible") and [sickness](/wiki/Potion_of_sickness "Potion of sickness") become uncursed [fruit juice](/wiki/Potion_of_fruit_juice "Potion of fruit juice")
  - potions of [booze](/wiki/Potion_of_booze "Potion of booze"), [fruit juice](/wiki/Potion_of_fruit_juice "Potion of fruit juice"), and [oil](/wiki/Potion_of_oil "Potion of oil") are unchanged except for their BUC status

*"In short, cancellation is quite thorough."*

Except for certain scrolls, spellbooks, and potions, cancelled objects do not change type. Cancelling a [bag of holding](/wiki/Bag_of_holding "Bag of holding") or [magic lamp](/wiki/Magic_lamp "Magic lamp") will merely uncurse it, not turn it into a [sack](/wiki/Sack "Sack") or [oil lamp](/wiki/Oil_lamp "Oil lamp"). Cancelling an [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") will not turn it into a non-artifact. Cancellation has no effect on the objects inside a [container](/wiki/Container "Container").

Cancelled wands end up with (x:-1) charges. Cancelled wands can be recharged subject to normal restrictions on wand charging, but cannot be wrested; if they are zapped or engraved with, they will turn to dust.

Irina Rempt has written an excellent and thorough [spoiler on cancelling objects](http://web.archive.org/web/20100405073536/http://www.nethack.de/spoiler330/cancellation.txt). Consult it for more details.

## Cancelling yourself

If you zap a wand of cancellation at yourself, every item in your inventory (*except* the wand itself) will become [cancelled](#Cancellation_of_objects). Breaking a wand of cancellation that has charges will produce the same outcome. All equipment will revert to uncursed and +0, all spellbooks and scrolls will turn blank, etc. This affects only items, i. e. the naked player monster is not cancelled. Do not do this with a wand that you think is a wand of make invisible. Self-cancellation is one means of removing [cursed](/wiki/BUC "BUC") gear; just be sure to drop or bag everything else before zapping. Polymorphed players revert, unless [unchanging](/wiki/Unchanging "Unchanging").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

A corner case: You are immune to cancellation if you have [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance"), unless you are zapping yourself. Monsters cannot zap cancellation in Vanilla, so this matters only for the point of maximum power you lose when hit by [Magicbane](/wiki/Magicbane "Magicbane") (and unpolymorphing).

## Cancellation of monsters

Monsters have an opportunity to [resist](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") cancellation effects. If the monster fails, it is cancelled and loses most of its special abilities.

### Abilities stopped by cancellation

The following attacks and special abilities are entirely stopped by cancellation:

- Everything [magic cancellation](/wiki/Magic_cancellation "Magic cancellation") protects against, and passive versions of the same:

  - [Fire](/wiki/Fire "Fire") (e.g., a [fire ant](/wiki/Fire_ant "Fire ant")'s burning attack)
  - [Cold](/wiki/Cold "Cold") (e.g., a [winter wolf](/wiki/Winter_wolf "Winter wolf")'s breath)
  - [Shock](/wiki/Shock "Shock") (e.g., an [electric eel](/wiki/Electric_eel "Electric eel")'s bite)
  - [Sleep](/wiki/Sleep "Sleep") (e.g., a [homunculus](/wiki/Homunculus "Homunculus")' bite)
  - [Poison](/wiki/Poison "Poison") (e.g., a [killer bee](/wiki/Killer_bee "Killer bee")'s sting)
  - [Paralysis](/wiki/Paralysis "Paralysis") (e.g., a [guardian naga](/wiki/Guardian_naga "Guardian naga")'s bite)
  - [Drain life](/wiki/Drain_life "Drain life") (e.g., a [vampire](/wiki/Vampire "Vampire")'s bite)
  - [Sticky attack](/wiki/Sticky_attack "Sticky attack") (e.g., a [large mimic](/wiki/Large_mimic "Large mimic")'s claw)
  - [Lycanthropy](/wiki/Lycanthropy "Lycanthropy") (e.g., a [werejackal](/wiki/Werejackal "Werejackal")'s bite while it is in animal form)
  - [Slowing attack](/wiki/Slowing_attack "Slowing attack") (e.g., a [shade](/wiki/Shade "Shade")'s touch)
  - [Teleport](/wiki/Teleport "Teleport") by a [quantum mechanic](/wiki/Quantum_mechanic "Quantum mechanic")'s claw
  - [Sliming](/wiki/Sliming "Sliming") by a [green slime](/wiki/Green_slime "Green slime")'s touch
  - [Disenchanting](/wiki/Disenchanting "Disenchanting") by a [disenchanter](/wiki/Disenchanter "Disenchanter")'s claw
  - [Power](/wiki/Power "Power") draining by an [energy vortex](/wiki/Energy_vortex "Energy vortex")
  - Constitution draining [poison](/wiki/Poison "Poison") from a [rabid rat](/wiki/Rabid_rat "Rabid rat")'s bite
  - Dexterity draining [poison](/wiki/Poison "Poison") from a [quasit](/wiki/Quasit "Quasit")'s claw

- [Spellcasting](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell")

- [Gaze attacks](/wiki/Gaze_attack "Gaze attack")

- [Breath attacks](/wiki/Breath_attack "Breath attack") (e.g., from [dragons](/wiki/Dragon "Dragon"))

- [Erosion](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion") attacks ([rusting](/wiki/Rusting "Rusting"), [corroding](/wiki/Corroding "Corroding"), and [rotting](/wiki/Rotting "Rotting")) and passive erosion effects

- [Drowning attacks](/wiki/Drowning_attack "Drowning attack") (cancellation will prevent a [sea monster](/wiki/Sea_monster "Sea monster") from swinging itself around you, but if it is already holding you cancellation will not prevent drowning)

- [Blinding](/wiki/Blind "Blind") attacks by light (e.g., by a [yellow light](/wiki/Yellow_light "Yellow light"))

- [Confusion](/wiki/Confusion "Confusion") attacks (e.g., from [Yeenoghu](/wiki/Yeenoghu "Yeenoghu"))

- [Stunning](/wiki/Stun "Stun") attacks

- [Petrification](/wiki/Petrification "Petrification") attacks

- [Acid](/wiki/Acid "Acid") attacks

- [Seduction](/wiki/Seduction "Seduction") of [succubi](/wiki/Succubus "Succubus") and [incubi](/wiki/Incubus "Incubus") (by attack or #[chat](/wiki/Chat "Chat"))

- [Leprechaun](/wiki/Leprechaun "Leprechaun") gold stealing

- [Nymph](/wiki/Nymph "Nymph") item stealing

- [Gremlin](/wiki/Gremlin "Gremlin") intrinsic-stealing

- [Xan](/wiki/Xan "Xan") leg attack

- [Nurse](/wiki/Nurse "Nurse") healing attack

- [Dividing](/wiki/Division "Division") by [puddings](/wiki/Pudding "Pudding")

- [Exploding](/wiki/Explode "Explode") attacks from [spheres](/wiki/Sphere "Sphere") and [lights](/wiki/Light_\(monster_class\) "Light (monster class)")

- Mimicking ability of [mimics](/wiki/Mimic "Mimic")

- Spitting attacks (e.g., by cobras)

- The monster-sumoning abilities of some [major demons](/wiki/Major_demon "Major demon") and [lycanthropes](/wiki/Lycanthrope "Lycanthrope")

- [Coyote](/wiki/Coyote "Coyote") funny names

Cancelling [clay golems](/wiki/Clay_golem "Clay golem") causes them to be destroyed immediately (this is because they, according to legend, are animated by an inscription on their forehead, which the wand erases).

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

The ability of [zombies](/wiki/Zombie "Zombie") and [liches](/wiki/Lich "Lich") to raise corpses is also negated by cancellation.

As of [commit fae75f5](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/fae75f5930bf8e7707a31b019f7fe415c6705cdd), cancelling a [troll](/wiki/Troll_\(monster_class\) "Troll (monster class)") or its corpse will prevent it from reviving.

### Abilities not stopped by cancellation

Some attacks which are not magical in nature cannot be cancelled; these include:

- the special attacks of the [Riders](/wiki/Riders "Riders") (disease for [Pestilence](/wiki/Pestilence "Pestilence"), hunger for [Famine](/wiki/Famine "Famine"), and touch of death for [Death](/wiki/Death_\(monster\) "Death (monster)"))
- the blinding attack of [ravens](/wiki/Raven "Raven")
- a [mind flayer](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer")'s brain-sucking attack
- the passive attacks of [the Oracle](/wiki/Oracle_\(monster\) "Oracle (monster)")
- passive [acid](/wiki/Acid "Acid") splashing
- [Grabbing attacks](/wiki/Grabbing_attack "Grabbing attack") (e.g., an [owlbear](/wiki/Owlbear "Owlbear")'s hug)
- [Engulfing](/wiki/Engulfing "Engulfing")
- [Juiblex](/wiki/Juiblex "Juiblex")'s disease attack
- The [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor")'s amulet stealing
- corpses of [trolls](/wiki/Troll_\(monster_class\) "Troll (monster class)") and the [Riders](/wiki/Riders "Riders") returning to life
- a [cockatrice](/wiki/Cockatrice "Cockatrice") or [chickatrice](/wiki/Chickatrice "Chickatrice")'s hiss that can induce gradual [stoning](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning") - direct physical contact with it or its corpse will still cause immediate stoning.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

In addition to the changes to trolls above, a [displacer beast](/wiki/Displacer_beast "Displacer beast")'s natural [displacement](/wiki/Displacement "Displacement") defense is also unaffected by cancellation.

### Notes

Cancelling [Medusa](/wiki/Medusa "Medusa") removes her stoning gaze, which also means that she cannot be stoned with a reflecting item. Similarly, cancelling a floating eye means it cannot be paralyzed by its reflection.

Cancelling items inside a [shop](/wiki/Shop "Shop") will anger the [shopkeeper](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper").

### Un-cancelling

It is possible to un-cancel most monsters by stoning them and then casting [stone to flesh](/wiki/Stone_to_flesh "Stone to flesh") on their statue, though this does not work on a [foocubus](/wiki/Foocubus "Foocubus") or a [nymph](/wiki/Nymph "Nymph").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) Also, some monsters have [stoning resistance](/wiki/Stoning_resistance "Stoning resistance"), and [tiny-sized](/wiki/Tiny-sized "Tiny-sized") monsters will turn into [rocks](/wiki/Rock "Rock") or [meatballs](/wiki/Meatball "Meatball") in the process. You can also un-cancel most [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster") if they die and leave a [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") by [zapping](/wiki/Zapping "Zapping") a [wand of undead turning](/wiki/Wand_of_undead_turning "Wand of undead turning") - it will come back to life uncancelled.

## Cancelling the floor

[Engraving](/wiki/Engraving "Engraving") on the floor or [zapping](/wiki/Zap "Zap") downwards with a [wand of cancellation](/wiki/Wand_of_cancellation "Wand of cancellation") will cause any previously created engraving on the floor space to disappear.

- "The engraving on the \<floor> vanishes!"

This is the same result as for a [wand of make invisible](/wiki/Wand_of_make_invisible "Wand of make invisible") and a [wand of teleportation](/wiki/Wand_of_teleportation "Wand of teleportation"), so a wand of cancellation cannot be uniquely identified in this manner.

## Considering when to cancel

Suppose you need some blank scrolls and spellbooks and some potions of water, because you plan to use your [magic marker](/wiki/Magic_marker "Magic marker") and make [holy water](/wiki/Holy_water "Holy water"). If you have a [wand of cancellation](/wiki/Wand_of_cancellation "Wand of cancellation"), one strategy is to put all your junk scrolls, spellbooks, and potions into one pile, then zap it with only one charge. However, it is usually easier to [wet](/wiki/Wet "Wet") those kinds of items rather than cancelling them. The advantage of cancelling in the early game is that you do not need to use [fountains](/wiki/Fountain "Fountain"), which are sometimes rare, and can cause nasty side effects. Once you find a pool or moat, or break a fountain to make a pool, you can save cancellation for use against [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster").

A few items can be rendered useful by cancelling them: a perfectly useless cursed -5 pair of [levitation boots](/wiki/Levitation_boots "Levitation boots"), for example, will cancel to a perfectly good uncursed +0 pair.

Cancellation is usually the only way to uncurse a cursed [bag of holding](/wiki/Bag_of_holding "Bag of holding") without any drawbacks. If it is cursed, its weight is multiplied by 2; so if a player with a well filled blessed bag of holding dies, the bones file may contain a cursed bag of holding with 8 times the weight it had in the previous game. This will probably make it too heavy for you to be able to pick it up and uncurse it, even if you have maximized your [carrying capacity](/wiki/Carrying_capacity "Carrying capacity") and are carrying no other items. You can still [loot](/wiki/Loot "Loot") or [tip](/wiki/Tip "Tip") it, but if you do this, every item in the bag has a 1⁄13 chance of vanishing. The best tactic is to pick up anything from the bones pile that can be damaged by cancellation (especially wands, because their beatitude is mostly irrelevant anyway), and cancel the remaining items. The contents of the bag, just like with any other container, will not be cancelled.

If you are wielding a cursed two-handed weapon in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"), you may have problems uncursing it if your [scrolls of remove curse](/wiki/Scroll_of_remove_curse "Scroll of remove curse") and [holy water](/wiki/Holy_water "Holy water") are all stored in containers (which you cannot open), because neither prayer nor spellcasting is possible in that state. If you cannot leave Gehennom without lifting the curse (e.g. because you have no free hands to gain levitation for [Juiblex](/wiki/Juiblex "Juiblex")'s lair), you may have to resort to dropping everything you can, then cancelling yourself. This will also cancel all the rest of your worn equipment, and so is only recommended in emergencies. (Some players drop potions of holy water in strategic places as a preventive measure.) [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0") has added the [tip](/wiki/Tip "Tip") command precisely to deal with such emergencies.

## Variants

Monsters in [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack"), and [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") can zap wands of cancellation at the player. Study the [wand of cancellation](/wiki/Wand_of_cancellation "Wand of cancellation") article for more details.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [gypsies](/wiki/Gypsies "Gypsies") are cancelled after they gave a wish, and cannot be [un-cancelled](#Un-cancelling).

Cancelling a monster by any means also has a chance of cancelling some of its items.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [zap.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 2258](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/zap.c#line2258 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/zap.c")
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [zap.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 511](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/zap.c#line511 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/zap.c")

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.1. Click here for more information.](/images/d/d3/Nh361-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.1. Click here for more information.")

**This page may need to be updated for the [current version](/wiki/Current_version "Current version") of *NetHack*.**

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1"). Information on this page may be out of date.

**Editors:** After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-361}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.
html:
Cancellation

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
For the cancellation effects caused by armor, see Magic cancellation.

Cancellation is the term for removing magical charges and blessed/cursed status from an object or disabling the special attack of a monster. The most common source of cancellation is the wand of cancellation. A few are able to use the spellbook of cancellation. Magicbane can sometimes cancel things it hits. Foocubi can spontaneously become cancelled. Some potions can be transformed by dipping things in them, but this is not quite cancellation. Gremlins can also use their intrinsic-stealing attack to cancel other monsters.

Contents

  • 1 Cancellation of objects
  • 2 Cancelling yourself
  • 3 Cancellation of monsters
    • 3.1 Abilities stopped by cancellation
    • 3.2 Abilities not stopped by cancellation
    • 3.3 Notes
    • 3.4 Un-cancelling
  • 4 Cancelling the floor
  • 5 Considering when to cancel
  • 6 Variants
    • 6.1 SLASH'EM
  • 7 References

Cancellation of objects

Cancellation has the following effects on objects:

  • the object becomes uncursed
  • the object's enchantment is set to +0 (applies to weapons, weapon-tools, and armor)
  • all charges are removed from the object if it is magical (wands to (x:-1), magical tools to (x:0), rings to +0); non-magical tools, the wand of nothing, and the wand of cancellation do not lose charges
  • scrolls and spellbooks (except the scroll of mail and spellbook of cancellation) are blanked
  • most potions are converted to uncursed water
    • potions of see invisible and sickness become uncursed fruit juice
    • potions of booze, fruit juice, and oil are unchanged except for their BUC status

"In short, cancellation is quite thorough."

Except for certain scrolls, spellbooks, and potions, cancelled objects do not change type. Cancelling a bag of holding or magic lamp will merely uncurse it, not turn it into a sack or oil lamp. Cancelling an artifact will not turn it into a non-artifact. Cancellation has no effect on the objects inside a container.

Cancelled wands end up with (x:-1) charges. Cancelled wands can be recharged subject to normal restrictions on wand charging, but cannot be wrested; if they are zapped or engraved with, they will turn to dust.

Irina Rempt has written an excellent and thorough spoiler on cancelling objects. Consult it for more details.

Cancelling yourself

If you zap a wand of cancellation at yourself, every item in your inventory (except the wand itself) will become cancelled. Breaking a wand of cancellation that has charges will produce the same outcome. All equipment will revert to uncursed and +0, all spellbooks and scrolls will turn blank, etc. This affects only items, i. e. the naked player monster is not cancelled. Do not do this with a wand that you think is a wand of make invisible. Self-cancellation is one means of removing cursed gear; just be sure to drop or bag everything else before zapping. Polymorphed players revert, unless unchanging.[1]

A corner case: You are immune to cancellation if you have magic resistance, unless you are zapping yourself. Monsters cannot zap cancellation in Vanilla, so this matters only for the point of maximum power you lose when hit by Magicbane (and unpolymorphing).

Cancellation of monsters

Monsters have an opportunity to resist cancellation effects. If the monster fails, it is cancelled and loses most of its special abilities.

Abilities stopped by cancellation

The following attacks and special abilities are entirely stopped by cancellation:

  • Everything magic cancellation protects against, and passive versions of the same:
    • Fire (e.g., a fire ant's burning attack)
    • Cold (e.g., a winter wolf's breath)
    • Shock (e.g., an electric eel's bite)
    • Sleep (e.g., a homunculus' bite)
    • Poison (e.g., a killer bee's sting)
    • Paralysis (e.g., a guardian naga's bite)
    • Drain life (e.g., a vampire's bite)
    • Sticky attack (e.g., a large mimic's claw)
    • Lycanthropy (e.g., a werejackal's bite while it is in animal form)
    • Slowing attack (e.g., a shade's touch)
    • Teleport by a quantum mechanic's claw
    • Sliming by a green slime's touch
    • Disenchanting by a disenchanter's claw
    • Power draining by an energy vortex
    • Constitution draining poison from a rabid rat's bite
    • Dexterity draining poison from a quasit's claw
  • Spellcasting
  • Gaze attacks
  • Breath attacks (e.g., from dragons)
  • Erosion attacks (rusting, corroding, and rotting) and passive erosion effects
  • Drowning attacks (cancellation will prevent a sea monster from swinging itself around you, but if it is already holding you cancellation will not prevent drowning)
  • Blinding attacks by light (e.g., by a yellow light)
  • Confusion attacks (e.g., from Yeenoghu)
  • Stunning attacks
  • Petrification attacks
  • Acid attacks
  • Seduction of succubi and incubi (by attack or #chat)
  • Leprechaun gold stealing
  • Nymph item stealing
  • Gremlin intrinsic-stealing
  • Xan leg attack
  • Nurse healing attack
  • Dividing by puddings
  • Exploding attacks from spheres and lights
  • Mimicking ability of mimics
  • Spitting attacks (e.g., by cobras)
  • The monster-sumoning abilities of some major demons and lycanthropes
  • Coyote funny names

Cancelling clay golems causes them to be destroyed immediately (this is because they, according to legend, are animated by an inscription on their forehead, which the wand erases).

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

The ability of zombies and liches to raise corpses is also negated by cancellation.

As of commit fae75f5, cancelling a troll or its corpse will prevent it from reviving.

Abilities not stopped by cancellation

Some attacks which are not magical in nature cannot be cancelled; these include:

  • the special attacks of the Riders (disease for Pestilence, hunger for Famine, and touch of death for Death)
  • the blinding attack of ravens
  • a mind flayer's brain-sucking attack
  • the passive attacks of the Oracle
  • passive acid splashing
  • Grabbing attacks (e.g., an owlbear's hug)
  • Engulfing
  • Juiblex's disease attack
  • The Wizard of Yendor's amulet stealing
  • corpses of trolls and the Riders returning to life
  • a cockatrice or chickatrice's hiss that can induce gradual stoning - direct physical contact with it or its corpse will still cause immediate stoning.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

In addition to the changes to trolls above, a displacer beast's natural displacement defense is also unaffected by cancellation.

Notes

Cancelling Medusa removes her stoning gaze, which also means that she cannot be stoned with a reflecting item. Similarly, cancelling a floating eye means it cannot be paralyzed by its reflection.

Cancelling items inside a shop will anger the shopkeeper.

Un-cancelling

It is possible to un-cancel most monsters by stoning them and then casting stone to flesh on their statue, though this does not work on a foocubus or a nymph.[2] Also, some monsters have stoning resistance, and tiny-sized monsters will turn into rocks or meatballs in the process. You can also un-cancel most monsters if they die and leave a corpse by zapping a wand of undead turning - it will come back to life uncancelled.

Cancelling the floor

Engraving on the floor or zapping downwards with a wand of cancellation will cause any previously created engraving on the floor space to disappear.

"The engraving on the <floor> vanishes!"

This is the same result as for a wand of make invisible and a wand of teleportation, so a wand of cancellation cannot be uniquely identified in this manner.

Considering when to cancel

Suppose you need some blank scrolls and spellbooks and some potions of water, because you plan to use your magic marker and make holy water. If you have a wand of cancellation, one strategy is to put all your junk scrolls, spellbooks, and potions into one pile, then zap it with only one charge. However, it is usually easier to wet those kinds of items rather than cancelling them. The advantage of cancelling in the early game is that you do not need to use fountains, which are sometimes rare, and can cause nasty side effects. Once you find a pool or moat, or break a fountain to make a pool, you can save cancellation for use against monsters.

A few items can be rendered useful by cancelling them: a perfectly useless cursed -5 pair of levitation boots, for example, will cancel to a perfectly good uncursed +0 pair.

Cancellation is usually the only way to uncurse a cursed bag of holding without any drawbacks. If it is cursed, its weight is multiplied by 2; so if a player with a well filled blessed bag of holding dies, the bones file may contain a cursed bag of holding with 8 times the weight it had in the previous game. This will probably make it too heavy for you to be able to pick it up and uncurse it, even if you have maximized your carrying capacity and are carrying no other items. You can still loot or tip it, but if you do this, every item in the bag has a 1⁄13 chance of vanishing. The best tactic is to pick up anything from the bones pile that can be damaged by cancellation (especially wands, because their beatitude is mostly irrelevant anyway), and cancel the remaining items. The contents of the bag, just like with any other container, will not be cancelled.

If you are wielding a cursed two-handed weapon in Gehennom, you may have problems uncursing it if your scrolls of remove curse and holy water are all stored in containers (which you cannot open), because neither prayer nor spellcasting is possible in that state. If you cannot leave Gehennom without lifting the curse (e.g. because you have no free hands to gain levitation for Juiblex's lair), you may have to resort to dropping everything you can, then cancelling yourself. This will also cancel all the rest of your worn equipment, and so is only recommended in emergencies. (Some players drop potions of holy water in strategic places as a preventive measure.) NetHack 3.6.0 has added the tip command precisely to deal with such emergencies.

Variants

Monsters in GruntHack, SLASH'EM, FIQHack, and EvilHack can zap wands of cancellation at the player. Study the wand of cancellation article for more details.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, gypsies are cancelled after they gave a wish, and cannot be un-cancelled.

Cancelling a monster by any means also has a chance of cancelling some of its items.

References

  1. ↑ zap.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 2258
  2. ↑ zap.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 511

This page may need to be updated for the current version of NetHack.

It may contain text specific to NetHack 3.6.1. Information on this page may be out of date.

rawPage:
{{For|the cancellation effects caused by armor|Magic cancellation}}

'''Cancellation''' is the term for removing magical charges and [[BUC|blessed/cursed]] status from an object or disabling the special attack of a monster. The most common source of cancellation is the [[wand of cancellation]]. A few are able to use the [[spellbook of cancellation]]. [[Magicbane]] can sometimes cancel things it hits. [[Foocubi]] can spontaneously become cancelled. Some [[potion]]s can be transformed by dipping [[unicorn horn|thin]][[amethyst stone|gs]] in them, but this is not quite cancellation. [[Gremlin]]s can also use their intrinsic-stealing attack to cancel other monsters.

== Cancellation of objects ==
Cancellation has the following effects on objects:
* the object becomes [[uncursed]]
* the object's enchantment is set to +0 (applies to [[weapon]]s, [[weapon-tool]]s, and [[armor]])
* all charges are removed from the object if it is magical ([[wand]]s to (x:-1), magical [[tool]]s to (x:0), [[ring]]s to +0); non-magical tools, the [[wand of nothing]], and the [[wand of cancellation]] do not lose charges
* [[scroll]]s and [[spellbook]]s (except the [[scroll of mail]] and [[spellbook of cancellation]]) are blanked
* most [[potion]]s are converted to uncursed water
** potions of [[potion of see invisible|see invisible]] and [[potion of sickness|sickness]] become uncursed [[potion of fruit juice|fruit juice]]
** potions of [[potion of booze|booze]], [[potion of fruit juice|fruit juice]], and [[potion of oil|oil]] are unchanged except for their BUC status

''"In short, cancellation is quite thorough."''

Except for certain scrolls, spellbooks, and potions, cancelled objects do not change type. Cancelling a [[bag of holding]] or [[magic lamp]] will merely uncurse it, not turn it into a [[sack]] or [[oil lamp]]. Cancelling an [[artifact]] will not turn it into a non-artifact. Cancellation has no effect on the objects inside a [[container]].

Cancelled wands end up with (x:-1) charges. Cancelled wands can be recharged subject to normal restrictions on wand charging, but cannot be wrested; if they are zapped or engraved with, they will turn to dust.

Irina Rempt has written an excellent and thorough [http://web.archive.org/web/20100405073536/http://www.nethack.de/spoiler330/cancellation.txt spoiler on cancelling objects]. Consult it for more details.

== Cancelling yourself ==
If you zap a wand of cancellation at yourself, every item in your inventory (''except'' the wand itself) will become [[#Cancellation of objects|cancelled]]. Breaking a wand of cancellation that has charges will produce the same outcome. All equipment will revert to uncursed and +0, all spellbooks and scrolls will turn blank, etc. This affects only items, i. e. the naked player monster is not cancelled. Do not do this with a wand that you think is a wand of make invisible. Self-cancellation is one means of removing [[BUC|cursed]] gear; just be sure to drop or bag everything else before zapping. Polymorphed players revert, unless [[unchanging]].{{refsrc|zap.c|2258}}

A corner case: You are immune to cancellation if you have [[magic resistance]], unless you are zapping yourself. Monsters cannot zap cancellation in Vanilla, so <!--What is the following phrase trying to say? -->this matters only for the point of maximum power you lose when hit by [[Magicbane]] (and unpolymorphing).

== Cancellation of monsters ==
Monsters have an opportunity to [[Magic resistance (monster)|resist]] cancellation effects. If the monster fails, it is cancelled and loses most of its special abilities.

===Abilities stopped by cancellation===
The following attacks and special abilities are entirely stopped by cancellation:
* Everything [[magic cancellation]] protects against, and passive versions of the same:
** [[Fire]] (e.g., a [[fire ant]]'s burning attack)
** [[Cold]] (e.g., a [[winter wolf]]'s breath)
** [[Shock]] (e.g., an [[electric eel]]'s bite)
** [[Sleep]] (e.g., a [[homunculus]]' bite)
** [[Poison]] (e.g., a [[killer bee]]'s sting)
** [[Paralysis]] (e.g., a [[guardian naga]]'s bite)
** [[Drain life]] (e.g., a [[vampire]]'s bite)
** [[Sticky attack]] (e.g., a [[large mimic]]'s claw)
** [[Lycanthropy]] (e.g., a [[werejackal]]'s bite while it is in animal form)
** [[Slowing attack]] (e.g., a [[shade]]'s touch)
** [[Teleport]] by a [[quantum mechanic]]'s claw
** [[Sliming]] by a [[green slime]]'s touch
** [[Disenchanting]] by a [[disenchanter]]'s claw
** [[Power]] draining by an [[energy vortex]]
** Constitution draining [[poison]] from a [[rabid rat]]'s bite
** Dexterity draining [[poison]] from a [[quasit]]'s claw
* [[Monster spell|Spellcasting]]
* [[Gaze attack]]s
* [[Breath attack]]s (e.g., from [[dragon]]s)
* [[Erosion]] attacks ([[rusting]], [[corroding]], and [[rotting]]) and passive erosion effects
* [[Drowning attack]]s (cancellation will prevent a [[sea monster]] from swinging itself around you, but if it is already holding you cancellation will not prevent drowning)
* [[Blind]]ing attacks by light (e.g., by a [[yellow light]])
* [[Confusion]] attacks (e.g., from [[Yeenoghu]])
* [[Stun]]ning attacks
* [[Petrification]] attacks
* [[Acid]] attacks
* [[Seduction]] of [[succubus|succubi]] and [[incubus|incubi]] (by attack or #[[chat]])
* [[Leprechaun]] gold stealing
* [[Nymph]] item stealing
* [[Gremlin]] intrinsic-stealing
* [[Xan]] leg attack
* [[Nurse]] healing attack
* [[Division|Dividing]] by [[pudding]]s
* [[Explode|Exploding]] attacks from [[sphere]]s and [[Light (monster class)|lights]]
* Mimicking ability of [[mimic]]s
* Spitting attacks (e.g., by cobras)
* The monster-sumoning abilities of some [[major demon]]s and [[lycanthrope]]s
* [[Coyote]] funny names

Cancelling [[clay golem]]s causes them to be destroyed immediately (this is because they, according to legend, are animated by an inscription on their forehead, which the wand erases).

{{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|The ability of [[zombie]]s and [[lich]]es to raise corpses is also negated by cancellation.

As of {{commit|fae75f5930bf8e7707a31b019f7fe415c6705cdd|commit fae75f5}}, cancelling a [[Troll (monster class)|troll]] or its corpse will prevent it from reviving.}}

===Abilities not stopped by cancellation===
Some attacks which are not magical in nature cannot be cancelled; these include:
* the special attacks of the [[Riders]] (disease for [[Pestilence]], hunger for [[Famine]], and touch of death for [[Death (monster)|Death]])
* the blinding attack of [[raven]]s
* a [[mind flayer]]'s brain-sucking attack
* the passive attacks of [[Oracle (monster)|the Oracle]]
* passive [[acid]] splashing
* [[Grabbing attack]]s (e.g., an [[owlbear]]'s hug)
* [[Engulfing]]
* [[Juiblex]]'s disease attack
* The [[Wizard of Yendor]]'s amulet stealing
* corpses of [[Troll (monster class)|trolls]] and the [[Riders]] returning to life
* a [[cockatrice]] or [[chickatrice]]'s hiss that can induce gradual [[stoning]] - direct physical contact with it or its corpse will still cause immediate stoning.

{{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|In addition to the changes to trolls above, a [[displacer beast]]'s natural [[displacement]] defense is also unaffected by cancellation.}}

===Notes===
Cancelling [[Medusa]] removes her stoning gaze, which also means that she cannot be stoned with a reflecting item. Similarly, cancelling a floating eye means it cannot be paralyzed by its reflection.

Cancelling items inside a [[shop]] will anger the [[shopkeeper]].

===Un-cancelling===
It is possible to un-cancel most monsters by stoning them and then casting [[stone to flesh]] on their statue, though this does not work on a [[foocubus]] or a [[nymph]].{{refsrc|zap.c|511}} Also, some monsters have [[stoning resistance]], and [[tiny-sized]] monsters will turn into [[rock]]s or [[meatball]]s in the process. You can also un-cancel most [[monster]]s if they die and leave a [[corpse]] by [[zapping]] a [[wand of undead turning]] - it will come back to life uncancelled.

==Cancelling the floor==
[[Engraving]] on the floor or [[zap]]ping downwards with a [[wand of cancellation]] will cause any previously created engraving on the floor space to disappear.

; "The engraving on the <floor> vanishes!"

This is the same result as for a [[wand of make invisible]] and a [[wand of teleportation]], so a wand of cancellation cannot be uniquely identified in this manner.

==Considering when to cancel==
Suppose you need some blank scrolls and spellbooks and some potions of water, because you plan to use your [[magic marker]] and make [[holy water]]. If you have a [[wand of cancellation]], one strategy is to put all your junk scrolls, spellbooks, and potions into one pile, then zap it with only one charge. However, it is usually easier to [[wet]] those kinds of items rather than cancelling them. The advantage of cancelling in the early game is that you do not need to use [[fountain]]s, which are sometimes rare, and can cause nasty side effects. Once you find a pool or moat, or break a fountain to make a pool, you can save cancellation for use against [[monster]]s.

A few items can be rendered useful by cancelling them: a perfectly useless cursed -5 pair of [[levitation boots]], for example, will cancel to a perfectly good uncursed +0 pair.

Cancellation is usually the only way to uncurse a cursed [[bag of holding]] without any drawbacks. If it is cursed, its weight is multiplied by 2; so if a player with a well filled blessed bag of holding dies, the bones file may contain a cursed bag of holding with 8 times the weight it had in the previous game. This will probably make it too heavy for you to be able to pick it up and uncurse it, even if you have maximized your [[carrying capacity]] and are carrying no other items. You can still [[loot]] or [[tip]] it, but if you do this, every item in the bag has a {{frac|13}} chance of vanishing. The best tactic is to pick up anything from the bones pile that can be damaged by cancellation (especially wands, because their beatitude is mostly irrelevant anyway), and cancel the remaining items. The contents of the bag, just like with any other container, will not be cancelled.

If you are wielding a cursed two-handed weapon in [[Gehennom]], you may have problems uncursing it if your [[scroll of remove curse|scrolls of remove curse]] and [[holy water]] are all stored in containers (which you cannot open), because neither prayer nor spellcasting is possible in that state. If you cannot leave Gehennom without lifting the curse (e.g. because you have no free hands to gain levitation for [[Juiblex]]'s lair), you may have to resort to dropping everything you can, then cancelling yourself. This will also cancel all the rest of your worn equipment, and so is only recommended in emergencies. (Some players drop potions of holy water in strategic places as a preventive measure.) [[NetHack 3.6.0]] has added the [[tip]] command precisely to deal with such emergencies.

==Variants==
Monsters in [[GruntHack]], [[SLASH'EM]], [[FIQHack]], and [[EvilHack]] can zap wands of cancellation at the player. Study the [[wand of cancellation]] article for more details.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], [[gypsies]] are cancelled after they gave a wish, and cannot be [[#Un-cancelling|un-cancelled]].

Cancelling a monster by any means also has a chance of cancelling some of its items.
